file_insights.changes_made: Added aria-label attributes to two password visibility toggle buttons
components_affected: IconButton password visibility toggle (appears twice in form)

patterns_discovered.description: The same password visibility toggle button with identical onClick and icon logic is implemented twice in the LoginPage, likely for separate login form sections
patterns_discovered.impact: Code duplication that requires parallel maintenance - changes must be applied to both locations

patterns_discovered.description: Using ternary operator to set descriptive aria-labels that change based on showPassword state: 'Show password' when hidden, 'Hide password' when visible
patterns_discovered.impact: Provides clear, context-aware accessibility labels that accurately describe button functionality at any state

gotchas_discovered.description: The password visibility toggle appears twice in the file. Both instances needed the aria-label addition. Missing either one would create inconsistent accessibility across the form.

gotchas_discovered.gotcha: IconButton may not inherit default accessibility attributes
gotchas_discovered.description: Material-UI's IconButton component does not automatically provide semantic labels, requiring explicit aria-label props for screen reader users

approach_outcome.summary: Successfully added aria-label attributes to both password visibility toggle buttons in LoginPage
approach_outcome.implementation_details: Applied conditional aria-labels (showPassword ? 'Hide password' : 'Show password') to two IconButton instances at lines 280 and 341
approach_outcome.accessibility_impact: Screen reader users can now understand the purpose and current state of password visibility toggles
approach_outcome.code_quality: Minimal, focused change with proper conditional logic for state-aware labels

recommendations.rationale: The password visibility toggle appears twice with identical logic. Extract to a reusable PasswordVisibilityToggle component to eliminate duplication and ensure consistency
Ensure the added aria-labels are actually announced correctly by common screen readers (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver)

recommendations.recommendation: Apply same pattern to other form components
recommendations.rationale: Review other icon buttons throughout the application for similar accessibility gaps and apply consistent aria-label patterns
